itemDescription: Scottish Roman Catholic priest and tenor

wikipedia_page.main: Canon Sydney Alfred MacEwan (19 October 1908 – 25 September 1991) was a Scottish tenor, who sang traditional Scottish and Irish songs. His name has also been recorded as Alfred Sydney Marley MacEwan.

response: *25 September – Sydney MacEwan, singer of traditional Scottish and Irish songs, 82
* The singer Sydney MacEwan had built, and was for a time parish priest of St Margaret's Church in the town

Scottish tenor Sydney MacEwan recorded the song in 1936 and Irish tenor John McCormack recorded it in 1941.http://jopiepopie.blogspot.co.uk/2014/11/my-lagan-love-1904-she-moved-thro-fair.html - this page contains information on other early recordings

link_mentions.page: List of University of Glasgow people
response: * Sydney MacEwan, tenor, singer of Scottish and Irish traditional songs
*25 September – Sydney MacEwan, singer of traditional Scottish and Irish songs, 82

People from Springburn include Scottish International footballer James McFadden, singer (tenor) Sydney MacEwan, musician Duncan Campbell, comedian, author and talk show host Craig Ferguson, broadcasters and writers Tom Weir MBE and his sister Molly, politicians Paul Sweeney, John McAllion and Frank McAveety. Springburn's former MP, Michael Martin, was the Speaker of the House of Commons from 2000-09. Martin Boyd, a local resident, was the last man in the UK hanged for rape.

link_mentions.page: List of people associated with the Royal Academy of Music

response: While living in Ireland, he became interested in church music, and composed a full-scale St Patrick's Mass, which was recorded by the Trinity Chorale in 1971 with the composer conducting.Celtic Note: St Patrick's Mass It was followed a year later by the Mass of St. Francis of Assisi. This was recorded with the Cork Children's Choir and the Scottish tenor/celebrant Canon Sydney MacEwan and released in November 1972. The song  "Suffer Little Children" from the Mass was released as a single in 1973 and reached No 3 in the Irish charts, remaining in the charts for five months. It is regularly used as a communion hymn in Catholic churches.Celtic Note: Mass of St. Francis of Assisi
* 19 October – Sydney MacEwan, singer and priest (died 1991)
